jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

8400A1211FF74B698C8C829CA166644A.description: Discuss the implications that banning dance could have in society

912B9F996E4D43C58016D4C4E6A3BECF.description: View and participate in dances inspired by the Renaissance era

2C28BF13C11B4EE7A62441B4693887BE.description: Examine the similarities and differences between dance steps within various cultures

DDE1842DC0FD43BEA5E69E4B662133FB.description: Experience traditional dances from colonial Canada

FA2E7CF83E524DC38EFBC6C371A97EEB.description: New dance forms can emerge based on the blending of cultural dance practices.

27D15261F0D7490E80E39D9FECD879BC.description: New dance forms can emerge based on the blending of cultural dance practices.

B5CE70E71D424FB98349C687D2B48FC8.description: New dance forms can emerge based on the blending of cultural dance practices.

C059977AD33C48B4992E69A8AA46D2FB.description:
Dance has changed over time as
communities and cultures have
evolved

1404228202FD4E648595975DDACE08FF.description: Social dancing was forbidden in some societies during the Protestant Reformation

8443A6ED37BF496693B867DD2B3CB317.description: During the Protestant Reformation, some religious groups opposed dance because of its non-religious (secular) nature

38323D741EA744EAAF2C17369416DA5A.description: European courts participated in a variety of dances, which can include basse danse pavane galliard volta tarantella

3AA6E684F92C43DB8B349AB68FDE4F8B.description: Queen Elizabeth I enjoyed dance and encouraged English country dances in her court.

BAF12E518ACA4AE980CC584F061F3660.description: Dance masters instructed the nobility on dance steps, posture, and etiquette

CD6228AE12E24A8480E76E9AC6974A32.description: Dance masters instructed the nobility on dance steps, posture, and etiquette

1407F47438784BB2B8BD6B175B3B0107.description: Dance masters instructed the nobility on dance steps, posture, and etiquette

1CBB90C794A044F98D7F4D7D5C4E1077.description: Jugglers from the Middle Ages transitioned into dancers and were highly sought after as dance masters

24B23A3B727D4737B8FFD5CF22BE0118.description: The Renaissance era was about all people bettering themselves through education, literature, science, and the arts

D3911105048E40AB85969DF5889DA849.description:
Settlers danced in their new Canadian and Albertan communities for a variety of reasons, including to feel connected to their homeland to socialize with other members
of the community
to have fun
to pass along cultural traditions
and a sense of place to younger
generations

501C51C46BA14620B7FE734689A101C0.description: Metis jigging is a dance form of French-Canadian, Scottish, and First Nations origins

3D9843CAF7844C2D8E831F732A9CEFE2.description: Some traditional First Nations dances were modified to align with European styles of dance and can include men's fancy dance women's fancy dance women's fancy shawl dance

BDD8D0E4374E43B7981BBAACDE538D07.description: First Nations and Inuit traditional cultural practices and traditional dances were banned by the Canadian government

2E1340B923BB4171BF031127BB6D72E8.description: First Nations and Inuit traditional cultural practices and traditional dances were banned by the Canadian government

D2FAB3777D7942689C0C390C86C6C75F.description: European dances were introduced to the Canadian landscape with the arrival of settlers from France in the 1500s and Britain in the 1600s, and can include folk dance en rond rouette, circle, and partner dances ballet longways dances and square dances

0D8814AF5EAA4AC9A47A1760F169EF44.description: Change that occurred in societies of the past has influenced how dance is performed and shared today

B519C70300274192B3305D291672DDE0.description: Students investigate how change influenced dance throughout history

FEEB0BD0C144439D8372E068CF855218.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate.

14FA154791514F90891E1DBE114B4268.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in dance

B3BF88EB96EE41AE87935D3EC3026ABC.description: Practise giving and receiving feedback in the creation of a narrative in dance

9B83631348E54D4092AEEBE56AB6B55B.description: Explore how narratives are expressed through First Nations, Metis, or Inuit movement and dance

348FB60401984D47AAA3D8DF5707C91F.description: Collaborate to create a narrative that includes a beginning, problem, and resolution

4A0F7ACC7D624D75B4A92B295BA6FA68.description: Create sections of improvised movements within a given choreographic form

26C4DDF9BE99412EAB234434768E74A4.description: Perform dances based on a narrative in various styles, in various genres, and from different time periods.

6340ACC2B95C45669DCAA155AE6C3218.description: A narrative in dance may be perceived by an audience in a way that differs from what the dancer intended

30874BD1B6E54173B6364B5FAA7C7A48.description: A narrative in dance can take an audience on a journey by entertaining and persuading.

9F24108C2B9C445DB4E53353A90A2AB1.description: A narrative in dance can communicate knowledge and understandings about the world.

2F1DB8AD4BDE4DF6BC02BBD627C4AAF0.description: A narrative in dance can describe past and present events and can be used to invent future possibilities

C35A9AFBC3F447C9B693F13562D019DB.description: Creative processes related to developing a narrative in dance can include generation of an idea problem solving receiving feedback reflection

7AD16FEE6EA440FFBC39E6554A5C94E7.description: Presenting dance to an audience can include considerations about the selection, sequencing, addition, or omission of movements the use of props the choice of music

4BD935843B3942D785CD4AB094C3B596.description: Parts of a narrative in dance may be excluded, leaving the audience to assume what happened before and after the narrative was presented

7A968736A67F482E89D1A94C61487385.description: Narrative in First Nations, Metis, and Inuit dances can originate from the land, including the wind water soil animals plants

03D22074B8654F42B52C272165E5AC44.description: Narrative in First Nations, Metis, and Inuit dances can originate from the land, including the wind water soil animals plants

E2868A1B9DB842D3AA7C4FDD87A01D89.description: A narrative in dance is represented in diverse ways and can provide connections to culture and history.

FBB8C5CE9B834D88A46DB9E18C555786.description: Narratives in dance can be based on imagination personal experiences stories, legends, and myths poetry historical or cultural events

B060B715CC4143A79C7A890C5D2A2D3A.description: A theme or concept can help shape the narrative that a dancer wants to express

B05075EBA9D74AB5A2D7426AA9CAB208.description: Narrative in dance can be enhanced by demonstrating the relationship between dancers using flocking contact improvisation mirroring tableau groups moving opposite to each other space, including proximity movement and facial expression

88760ACAF49C4EB88BD18E162CFFED18.description: Choreographic forms can give a narrative structure, including ABA (ternary) narrative ABACAD (recurring theme)

21D7417BD0814A0184A0A39AB1477C3F.description: Choreographic forms can give a narrative structure, including ABA (ternary) narrative ABACAD (recurring theme)

B7D03897A2964B56B49B6C15FA48D223.description: Narrative can be represented individually or collectively.

2F8DD4E7DC464093AA89C8E0340BA848.description: The structure of a narrative in dance can include a beginning, problem, and resolution

526FB9D03F754429A2E1E78F02E23A78.description: The structure of a narrative in dance can include a beginning, problem, and resolution

2DC71F2E14DA4AB4A95580DF444E2DF7.description: Students represent narrative based on a variety of inspirations and through the application of artistic choices

14D349A5C3D14158892FD4D99FF2B5FC.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

D568CE17577D4DC7918F67375DE88FC1.description: A narrative in dance may be perceived by an audience in a way that differs from what the dancer intended

CA27D02A2B4341DC8B1B2653335138D0.description: Improvisation uses a creative process to create and refine movement ideas.

4E72957464FB44628C8F15C23D871526.description: Improvisation is a method of generating ideas in dance.

CA2FDA7722DA4807939E31013AA49814.description: Improvisation is the spontaneous creation of movement

F6EC939039D44226B9E9F3656EEC9263.description: Improvisation is a form of dance that builds confidence and skills for performance allows exploration of new movements without the pressure to perform

4728FF2D75A2460A8E3BC67A37C44D01.description: Improvisation is a skill that draws upon memory recall and problem solving in the moment

1F5F944D86B74E4AA2AF08BCC672BB63.description: Warm-up activities in dance can include improvisational techniques

B8CC272E484745618C57A031A29035EF.description: Music components can direct improvised movements, including beat rhythm metre accent dynamics forms

69831121758F459AA972E39E2D12A1E3.description: Improvisation can occur in response to external stimuli, including music, props, images, sounds, texts, and artworks internal stimuli, including preferences for movements, emotions, and thoughts

DD9B2D87197D403FB267C66B642EC2C3.description: Creative risks can include working individually or in groups trying unfamiliar or new techniques working outside one's comfort zone

DB112C7E96FE40D7B06666C1473879D5.description: Improvisation in dance can involve taking creative risks in the generation of movement ideas

954C2AC9241746069B9FC53C88AAFCBB.description: Ideas expressed through improvisation can include anything a dancer wants to express.

7C0FB82328984ED193BA3790F30FA53B.description: The elements of dance can be applied to movements that are improvised

FF612F536CDC431BA6AD729F32989845.description: Choreographic forms that can incorporate improvised sections include ABACAD (recurring theme) call and response Improvised movement phrases that have a clear beginning and ending contribute to the structure of the dance idea.

5B4C9FCE65BB4E83B1DE54AC394D8CD4.description: Improvisation is a technique to structure a movement phrase, sequence, or entire dance

3D70913F8AF44B788FE71DE94ABF1B91.description: Dancing to various kinds of music, to text, or with partners can enhance experiences with improvisation

4335BA7A677D4D79AF3D6F4AC7CDB14D.description: Students examine the function of improvisation in dance

60AC12B0C5174BDF99BF50B4EEBFCE90.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles.
